data.title: Famous Birthdays on January 28
data.meta_description: Famous birthdays for the 28th of January. See which celebrities, historical figures, scientists and criminals were born on January 28.
data.text:
Birthdays 1 - 200 of 256

Li Shimin, Emperor Taizong of Tang, Emperor of China (626-49), born at Wugong (d. 649)

Thomas Aquinas

Italian theologian, Philosopher and Doctor of the Church (Summa Theologica) [birthdate is approximate], born in Roccasecca, Kingdom of Sicily

Queen Joan II of Navarre (d. 1349)

Henry VII

1st Tudor King of England (1485-1509), born in Pembroke Castle, Wales

Ludolph van Ceulen, German mathematician (d. 1610)

Cornelis Haga, Dutch lawyer and ambassador to Constantinople (1611-39) (d. 1654)

John Barclay, Scottish satirist writer and poet (Euphormio's Satyricon), born in Pont-à-Mousson, Lorraine, France (d. 1621)

Clement IX [Giulio Rospigliosi], Italian Pope (238th: 1667-69), born in Pistoia, Italy (d. 1669)

Giovanni Alfonso Borelli, mathematician and astronomer, born in Naples, Kingdom of Naples, Spanish Empire (now Italy) (d. 1679)

Johannes Hevelius, Polish astronomer who pioneered lunar topography (Prodromus Astronomiae - catalogue of over 1500 stars), born in Danzig (d. 1687)

Adrien Auzout, French astronomer (d. 1691)

Alfonso Marsh, English composer and lutenist, baptized in London, England (d. 1681)

Gottfried Vopelius, German hymn composer, born in Herwigsdorf, Electorate of Saxony, Holy Roman Empire (d. 1715)

Jan Maurits Quinkhard, Dutch portrait painter, born in Rees, Netherlands (d. 1772)

Johann Balthasar König, German Baroque composer, mainly of hymn music, born in Cannstatt, Duchy of Württemberg, Holy Roman Empire (d. 1758)

Gregor Werner, Austrian Baroque composer and kapellmeister, born in Ybbs an der Donau, Austria (d. 1766)

Charles Marie de La Condamine, French mathematician and geographer (d. 1774)

Hermanus Noordkerk, Dutch lawyer (d. 1771)

John Baskerville, English printer and type designer (printer to the University of Cambridge), baptized in Wolverley, Worcestershire, England (d. 1775)

Tokugawa Ieshige, Japanese shogun (d. 1761)

Jean-Baptiste Pigalle, French sculptor (Child with Cage, Mercury Fastening his Sandals), born in Paris (d. 1785)

Mustafa III, Ottoman Sultan (1757-74), born in Edirne Palace, Edirne, Ottoman Empire (d. 1774)

Johann Elias Schlegel, German critic and poet (d. 1749)

Johann Ernst Bach, German kapellmeister and composer, born in Eisenach, Duchy of Saxe-Eisenach, Holy Roman Empire (d. 1777)

Hans Adolf Friedrich von Eschstruth, German composer and lawyer, born in Homberg, Landgraviate of Hesse-Darmstadt. Holy Roman Empire (d. 1792)

Antonio Bartolomeo Bruni, Italian composer and conductor, born in Cuneo, Kingdom of Sardinia (d. 1821)

Frederick VI, King of Denmark (1808-39) and Norway (1808-1814), born in Christiansborg Palace, Copenhagen, Denmark (d. 1839)

Giovanni Battista Velluti, Italian castrato singer 'the last great castrato', born in Pausula, Papal States (d. 1861)

George Hamilton-Gordon

4th Earl of Aberdeen, Prime Minister of the United Kingdom (Peelite: 1852-55) and Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs (1841-46), born in Edinburgh, Scotland

(Louis Joseph) Ferdinand Hérold, French pianist, violinist, and composer of over twenty operas, born in Paris, Feance (d. 1833)

Robert McClure

Irish explorer who discovered the Northwest passage, born in Wexford, Ireland

Andrew Jackson Hamilton, American Brigadier General (Union Army), born in Huntsville, Alabama (d. 1875)

George Sewall Boutwell, MC (Union), (d. 1905)

Alexander Mackenzie

2nd Prime Minister of Canada (Liberal: 1873-78), born in Logierait, Scotland

George Edward Pickett, Major General (Confederate Army), (d. 1875)

Michel Abeloos, Flemish sculptor, born in Leuven (d. 1881)

1828 Thomas Carmichael Hindman, Jr., American attorney, and Confederate Army Major General, born in Knoxville Tennessee (d. 1868)

Henry Brevard Davidson, Brigadier General (Confederate Army), (d. 1899)

Franz Wüllner, German composer and conductor, born in Münster, Germany (d. 1902)

Charles George Gordon, British general (put down Taiping rebellion in China) and administrator (Governor-General of Sudan), born in London, England (d. 1885)

Henry Morton Stanley

Welsh journalist and African explorer (found Livingstone in Africa), born in Denbigh, Wales

Viktor Ernst Nessler, Alsatian composer, born in Baldenheim, Alsace (d. 1890)

Vasily Osipovich Klyuchevsky, Russian imperial historian, born in Penza Governorate, Russia (d. 1911)

George Wright, American Baseball HOF shortstop (NA pennant 1872-75 Boston Red Stockings; NL pennant 1877-78 Boston Red Caps, 1879 Providence Grays), born in Yonkers, New York (d. 1937)

Jose Martí y Perez, Cuban poet, essayist and politician (fought for independence from Spain), born in Havana, Cuba (d. 1895)

William Seward Burroughs, American inventor of the 1st workable adding machine, born in rural New York (d. 1898)

Eugène Dubois, Dutch palaeontologist who discovered human ancestor Pithecanthropus erectus "Java Man", born in Eisden, Netherlands (d. 1940) [1]

Ernst William Christmas, Australian painter (d. 1918)

Herbert Akroyd Stuart, English engineer - inventor of the first compression ignition engine (d. 1927)

Kaarlo Juho Ståhlberg, first president of Finland (d. 1952)

1865 Lala Lajpat Rai, Indian freedom fighter (d. 1928)

Frederic Lamond, Scottish composer, pupil of Liszt, born in Glasgow, Scotland (d. 1948)

1868 Julian Aguirre, Argentine composer, born in Buenos Aires, Argentina (d. 1924)

Colette

French author, novelist (Gigi, La Vagabonde) and actress, born in Paris, France

Monty Noble, Australian cricket all-rounder (42 Tests, 1 x 100, HS 133, 121 wickets, BB 7/17; NSW), born in Sydney, Australia (d. 1940)

Alex Smith, Scottish-American golfer (US Open 1906, 10), born in Carnoustie, Scotland (d. 1930)

1874 Ernst Rabel, Austrian-American lawyer, human rights activist, and author (The Conflict of Laws: A Comparative Study), born in Vienna, Austria (d. 1955)

Julian Antonio Carillo Trujillo, Mexican composer, musician and conductor (developed theory of microtonal music "The Thirteenth Sound"), born in Ahualulco, Mexico (d. 1965)

Walter Kollo, German composer of operettas, Singspiele, and popular songs (Der Juxbaron), born in Neidenburg, Kingdom of Prussia. (d. 1940)

Herbert Strudwick, English cricket wicketkeeper (28 Tests, 73 dismissals; Surrey CCC), born in Mitcham, England (d. 1970)

1880 Mary Boland, American comedienne and actress (Ruggles of Red Gap), born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania (d. 1965)

Pascual Orozco, Mexican revolutionary leader, born in Santa Inés, Mexico (d. 1915)

Auguste Piccard, Swiss scientist, explorer and balloonist (1st flight into stratosphere, by balloon), born in Basel, Switzerland (d. 1962)

1884 Jean Felix Piccard, Swiss scientist, explorer and balloonist (1st flight into stratosphere, by balloon), born in Basel, Switzerland (d. 1963)

1884 Lucien d'Azambuja, French astronomer (studied the solar chromosphere), born in Paris, France (d. 1970)

Hidetsugu Yagi, Japanese electrical engineer (d. 1976)

1886 Marthe Bibesco, Romanian writer (d. 1973)

Artur Rubinstein, Polish-American concert pianist, born in Łódź, Russian Empire (now Poland), (d. 1982)

Bill Doak, American baseball pitcher (NL ERA leader 1914, 21; St. Louis Cardinals), born in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania (d. 1954)

1891 Camille Melloy [Paepe], Belgian poet (Parfum des Buis), born in Melle (d. 1941)

1891 Karel Boleslav Jirak, Czech composer and pedagogue, born in Prague, Kingdom of Bohemia (now Czech Republic) (d. 1972)

Elliot Griffis, American composer, born in Boston, Massachusetts (d. 1967)

Valentin Kataev, novelist/playwright (Embezzled), born in Odessa Ukraine (d. 1986)

Vittorio Rieti, Jewish Italian-American composer, born in Alexandria, Egypt (d. 1994)

1898 Wies Moens, Flemish writer and historian, born in Sint-Gillis-bij-Dendermonde, Belgium (d. 1982)

Elias Simojoki, Finnish clergyman and politician (d. 1940)

1899 Zilner Randolph, American jazz trumpeter, arranger, and music educator, born in Dermott, Arkansas (d. 1994)

A. A. M. Stols, Dutch publisher (History of Ecuador), born in Maastricht, Netherlands (d. 1973)

1900 Alice Neel, American artist (d. 1984)

1900 Hermann Kesten, German writer (Allert de Lange), born in Pidvolochysk, Austro-Hungarian Empire (d. 1996)

1900 Michael Head, British organist, pianist, and composer, born in Eastbourne, England (d. 1976)

Kathleen Lonsdale, Irish-born British pacifist and crystallographer (one of 1st two women elected to Royal Society), born in Newbridge, Ireland (d. 1971)

1903 Lotte Stam-Beese, German-Dutch architect and urban planner who helped reconstruct Rotterdam after the war, born in Reisicht, Germany (d. 1989)

Canuplin, Filipino magician and bodabil entertainer (d. 1979)

Luther Simjian, Armenian-American Inventor (teleprompter and first self-posing portrait camera), born in Aintab, Ottoman Empire (d. 1997)

Harry van Kruiningen, Dutch painter and graphic artist, born in Kruiningen, Netherlands (d. 1996)

1906 Henry Foley, New Zealand cricket batsman (1 Test; NZ's first Test match; Wellington CA), born in Wellington (d. 1948)

Constantin Regamey, Ukranian pianist, composer and music critic, born in Kiev, Russian Empire (now Kyiv, Ukraine) (d. 1987)

1907 Henry Cotton, British golfer (British Open 1934, 1937, 1948), born in Holmes Chapel, Cheshire, England (d. 1987)

Paul Misraki [Misrachi], French jazz pianist, songwriter, and film score composer (Jean Renoir), born in Constantinople, Ottoman Empire (d. 1998)

Lionel Crabb "Buster", British Royal Navy diver (WW II-George Medal), born in London, England (d. 1956)

Arnold Moss, American actor (Loves of Carmen, Kim, Quebec, Viva Zapata), born in Brooklyn, New York (d. 1989)

Johan van Hulst, Dutch teacher who helped save 600 children from the Nazis, born in Amsterdam, Netherlands (d. 2018)

Jackson Pollock

American expressionist painter (Lavender Mist), born in Cody, Wyoming

Jan Masseus, Dutch composer, born in Rotterdam (d. 1999)

1913 Oliver Chesterton, British businessman (Chestertons Estate Agency) (d. 2007)

Nelson Olmsted [or Olmstead], American voice actor (Sleep No More), born in Minneapolis, Minnesota (d. 1992)

1918 Suzanne Flon, French actress (One Deadly Summer, Moulin Rouge), born in Le Kremlin-Bicêtre, Seine (d. 2005)

Alfred Marks, British actor and comedian (Desert Mice, Scream & Scream Again), born in Holborn, London (d. 1996)

Robert W. Holley, American biochemist who worked with RNA (Nobel Prize 1968), born in Los Gatos, California (d. 1991)

Henry Harris, British cell biologist (identified genes capable of suppressing cancers), born in Russia (d. 2014) [1]

Anthony Garner, director (Conservative Central Office)

1927 Don Fraser, American boxing promoter (LA venues; Sugar Ray Robinson, Ruben Olivares, George Foreman; known for colourful wardrobe, offbeat PR gimmicks), born in Blythe, California (d. 2019)

1927 J D Hughes, Principal (Ruskin College-Oxford)

1927 Ronnie Scott [Schatt], British jazz saxophonist and club-owner, born in Aldgate, East London, England (d. 1996)

1928 Slade Gorton, American politician (Sen-R-WA, 1981-87, 1989-2001), born in Chicago, Illinois (d. 2020)

Luis de Pablo, Spanish composer, and musicologist, born in Bilbao, Spain (d. 2021)
